text: okay my big advice always for people
trying to career transition is to think
about your previous career and what you
liked about that and what you didn't
like about that so if you're already
working in the healthcare industry do
you like that industry because if so
you're to have so much institutional
knowledge if you become a software
engineer in that industry once you
transition and so i think keeping that
in mind when you're looking for a mentor
is really important too of what are the
skill sets that or what are the things
that i want from my future career and
who is out there that has those things
and how can i uh
get the best information from them so
that they can guide my career in that
way
and also you don't have to have like a
year-long mentorship relationship with
somebody either you can just have a
one-time coffee chat and that's a much
smaller ask and can be pretty high
impact as well
that's true yeah and just i think
putting a little time boxing around it
is a smart idea um from speaking from
them i'm sure you have the same
experience having you know how much time
that you have to spend um and sort of
and as a mentee you know making sure to
say thank you
yes definitely definitely and make it a
two directional relationship too
don't have it be like a parasocial
person type relationship
give back in some way too and that's
like not monetary but
share your learning share your advice
you have some valuable contribution as
well the more mutual that a relationship
can be
the better
and i think that goes for networking
in general
[Music]
you
